statement: D. Two Pathstime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test64 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutAs you know, Bob's brother lives in Flatland. In Flatland there arencities, connected byn- 1two-way roads. The cities are numbered from 1 ton. You can get from one city to another moving along the roads.The «Two Paths» company, where Bob's brother works, has won a tender to repair two paths in Flatland. A path is a sequence of different cities, connected sequentially by roads. The company is allowed to choose by itself the paths to repair. The only condition they have to meet is that the two paths shouldn't cross (i.e. shouldn't have common cities).It is known that the profit, the «Two Paths» company will get, equals the product of the lengths of the two paths. Let's consider the length of each road equals 1, and the length of a path equals the amount of roads in it. Find the maximum possible profit for the company.InputThe first line contains an integern(2 ≤n≤ 200), wherenis the amount of cities in the country. There are $n$ cities connected by $n-1$ roads. Each road connects two different cities.  You need to choose two paths (sequences of cities connected by roads) that don't share any cities. The length of a path is the number of roads it contains.  Find the maximum possible product of the lengths of the two paths. 

The input will be:

* The first line contains the number of cities, $n$.
* The following $n-1$ lines each contain two numbers, representing a road connecting those two cities.

The output should be the maximum possible product of the lengths of the two paths.

You are given a graph with cities connected by roads.  Find the maximum profit you can get by choosing two non-overlapping paths in the graph. The profit is the product of the lengths of the two paths. The length of a path is the number of roads it contains.
